thm rpnnen2lem1(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2) {

  -| diffss(s0, s1)

  sylbir(wss(c0, cn), wceq(cfv(c2, c0), cmpt(s1, cn, cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), c0)))), wcel(c0, cpw(cn)))
  elpw2(c0, cn)
  fvmpt(s0, c0, cpw(cn), c2, cmpt(s1, cn, cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), c0))), cmpt(s1, cn, cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), cv(s0)))))
  mpteq2dv(s1, cn, cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), cv(s0))), cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), c0)), wceq(cv(s0), c0))
  ifbid(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wceq(cv(s0), c0), wcel(cv(s1), cv(s0)), wcel(cv(s1), c0))
  eleq2(cv(s0), c0, cv(s1))

  nnex()
  fvmpt(s1, c1, cn, cmpt(s1, cn, cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), c0))), cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, c1), nat0, wcel(c1, c0)), cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), c0)))
  ifbieq1d(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, c1), wceq(cv(s1), c1), wcel(cv(s1), c0), wcel(c1, c0))
  eleq1(cv(s1), c1, c0)
  oveq2(cv(s1), c1, co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp)
  eqid(cmpt(s1, cn, cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), c0))))
  ifex(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, c1), nat0, wcel(c1, c0))
  ovex(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, c1)
  c0ex()
  diff.cpw.s(s0, cn)
  diff.cmpt.s(s0, s1, cn, cif(co(co(nat1, cdiv, nat3), cexp, cv(s1)), nat0, wcel(cv(s1), c0)))
  diff.cn.s(s0)

  sylan9eq(((c2 ` c0)` c1), if(c1 ∈ c0,((1[÷]3)[^]c1), 0), ((s1 ∈ ℕ ↦ if(s1 ∈ c0,((1[÷]3)[^]s1), 0))` c1), c0 ⊆ ℕ, c1 ∈ ℕ)

  mpteq2dv(s1, cn, if(s1 ∈ s0,((1[÷]3)[^]s1), 0), if(s1 ∈ c0,((1[÷]3)[^]s1), 0), s0 = c0)

  eleq2(s0, c0, s1)
  mptex(s1, cn, if(s1 ∈ c0,((1[÷]3)[^]s1), 0))

  diff.cn.s(s0)

blocks.name: rpnnen2
blocks.content: The other half of ~ rpnnen , where we show an injection from sets of positive integers to real numbers. The obvious choice for this is binary expansion, but it has the unfortunate property that it does not produce an injection on numbers which end with all 0's or all 1's (the more well-known decimal version of this is ~ 0.999... ). Instead, we opt for a ternary expansion, which produces (a scaled version of) the Cantor set. Since the Cantor set is riddled with gaps, we can show that any two sequences that are not equal must differ somewhere, and when they do, they are placed a finite distance apart, thus ensuring that the map is injective. Our map assigns to each subset ` A ` of the positive integers the number ` sum_ k e. A ( 3 ^ -u k ) = sum_ k e. NN ( ( F `` A ) `` k ) ` , where ` ( ( F `` A ) `` k ) = if ( k e. A , ( 3 ^ -u k ) , 0 ) ) ` ( ~ rpnnen2lem1 ). This is an infinite sum of real numbers ( ~ rpnnen2lem2 ), and since ` A C_ B ` implies ` ( F `` A ) <_ ( F `` B ) ` ( ~ rpnnen2lem4 ) and ` ( F `` NN ) ` converges to ` 1 / 2 ` ( ~ rpnnen2lem3 ) by ~ geoisum1 , the sum is convergent to some real ( ~ rpnnen2lem5 and ~ rpnnen2lem6 ) by the comparison test for convergence ~ cvgcmp . The comparison test also tells us that ` A C_ B ` implies ` sum_ ( F `` A ) <_ sum_ ( F `` B ) ` ( ~ rpnnen2lem7 ). Putting it all together, if we have two sets ` x =/= y ` , there must differ somewhere, and so there must be an ` m ` such that ` A. n < m ( n e. x <-> n e. y ) ` but ` m e. ( x \ y ) ` or vice versa. In this case, we split off the first ` m - 1 ` terms ( ~ rpnnen2lem8 ) and cancel them ( ~ rpnnen2lem10 ), since these are the same for both sets. For the remaining terms, we use the subset property to establish that ` sum_ ( F `` y ) <_ sum_ ( F `` ( NN \ { m } ) ) ` and ` sum_ ( F `` { m } ) <_ sum_ ( F `` x ) ` (where these sums are only over ` ( ZZ>= `` m ) ` ), and since ` sum_ ( F `` ( NN \ { m } ) ) = ( 3 ^ -u m ) / 2 ` ( ~ rpnnen2lem9 ) and ` sum_ ( F `` { m } ) = ( 3 ^ -u m ) ` , we establish that ` sum_ ( F `` y ) < sum_ ( F `` x ) ` ( ~ rpnnen2lem11 ) so that they must be different. By contraposition ( ~ rpnnen2lem12 ), we find that this map is an injection. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 13-May-2013.) (Proof shortened by Mario Carneiro, 30-Apr-2014.) (Revised by NM, 17-Aug-2021.)

blocks.name: rpnnen
blocks.content: The cardinality of the continuum is the same as the powerset of ` _om ` . This is a stronger statement than ~ ruc , which only asserts that ` RR ` is uncountable, i.e. has a cardinality larger than ` _om ` . The main proof is in two parts, ~ rpnnen1 and ~ rpnnen2 , each showing an injection in one direction, and this last part uses ~ sbth to prove that the sets are equinumerous. By constructing explicit injections, we avoid the use of AC. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 13-May-2013.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 23-Aug-2014.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: rexpen

thm cpnnen() {
  ⊢ ℂ[≅]P(ℕ)
} = {
  entr3i(cc, P(ℕ), cr)
  entr3i(cr, cc, (ℝ × ℝ))
  rexpen()
  ax-mp((ℝ × ℝ)[≅]ℂ, ({ < < hs0, hs1 >, hs2 > |((hs0 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs0[+](i[×]hs1)))} :(ℝ × ℝ)↔ ℂ))
  cnref1o(hs3, hs4, { < < hs0, hs1 >, hs2 > |((hs0 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs0[+](i[×]hs1)))})
  eqtr4i({ < < hs0, hs1 >, hs2 > |((hs0 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs0[+](i[×]hs1)))}, (hs3 ∈ ℝ, hs4 ∈ ℝ ↦(hs3[+](i[×]hs4))), { < < hs3, hs4 >, hs2 > |((hs3 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs4 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs3[+](i[×]hs4)))})
  cbvoprab12v(hs0, hs1, hs2, hs3, hs4, ((hs0 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs0[+](i[×]hs1))), ((hs3 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs4 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs3[+](i[×]hs4))))
  anbi12d((hs0 = hs3 ∧ hs1 = hs4), (hs0 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℝ), hs2 =(hs0[+](i[×]hs1)), (hs3 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs4 ∈ ℝ), hs2 =(hs3[+](i[×]hs4)))
  bi2anan9(hs0 = hs3, hs1 = hs4, hs0 ∈ ℝ, hs1 ∈ ℝ, hs3 ∈ ℝ, hs4 ∈ ℝ)
  eleq1w(hs0, hs3, cr)
  eleq1w(hs1, hs4, cr)
  eqeq2d(hs2, (hs0[+](i[×]hs1)), (hs3[+](i[×]hs4)), (hs0 = hs3 ∧ hs1 = hs4))
  sylan2(hs0 = hs3, hs1 = hs4, (hs0[+](i[×]hs1))=(hs3[+](i[×]hs4)), (i[×]hs1)=(i[×]hs4))
  oveq2(hs1, hs4, ci, cmul)
  oveq12(hs0, hs3, (i[×]hs1), (i[×]hs4), caddc)
  df-mpo(hs3, hs4, hs2, cr, cr, (hs3[+](i[×]hs4)))
  f1oen({ < < hs0, hs1 >, hs2 > |((hs0 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs0[+](i[×]hs1)))}, (ℝ × ℝ), cc)
  xpex(cr, cr)
  reex()
  rpnnen()
  diff.hs3.s(hs4)
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.s(hs2)
  diff.hs0.s(hs3)
  diff.hs0.s(hs4)
  diff.hs1.s(hs2)
  diff.hs1.s(hs3)
  diff.hs1.s(hs4)
  diff.hs2.s(hs3)
  diff.hs2.s(hs4)
  diff.hs0.w(((hs3 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs4 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs3[+](i[×]hs4))))
  diff.hs1.w(((hs3 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs4 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs3[+](i[×]hs4))))
  diff.hs3.w(((hs0 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs0[+](i[×]hs1))))
  diff.hs4.w(((hs0 ∈ ℝ ∧ hs1 ∈ ℝ)∧ hs2 =(hs0[+](i[×]hs1))))
  diff.hs3.s(hs2)
  diff.hs4.s(hs2)
  diff.hs2.c(cr)
  diff.hs2.c((hs3[+](i[×]hs4)))
}

blocks.name: rucALT
blocks.content: Alternate proof of ~ ruc . This proof is a simple corollary of ~ rpnnen , which determines the exact cardinality of the reals. For an alternate proof discussed at ~ mmcomplex.html#uncountable , see ~ ruc . (Contributed by NM, 13-Oct-2004.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 13-May-2013.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: ruclem1
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ ruc (the reals are uncountable). Substitutions for the function ` D ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 28-May-2014.) (Revised by Fan Zheng, 6-Jun-2016.)

blocks.name: ruclem9
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ ruc . The first components of the ` G ` sequence are increasing, and the second components are decreasing. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 28-May-2014.)

blocks.name: ruclem10
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ ruc . Every first component of the ` G ` sequence is less than every second component. That is, the sequences form a chain a_1 ` < ` a_2 ` < ` ... ` < ` b_2 ` < ` b_1, where a_i are the first components and b_i are the second components. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 28-May-2014.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: ruc
blocks.content: The set of positive integers is strictly dominated by the set of real numbers, i.e. the real numbers are uncountable. The proof consists of lemmas ~ ruclem1 through ~ ruclem13 and this final piece. Our proof is based on the proof of Theorem 5.18 of [Truss] p. 114. See ~ ruclem13 for the function existence version of this theorem. For an informal discussion of this proof, see ~ mmcomplex.html#uncountable . For an alternate proof see ~ rucALT . This is Metamath 100 proof #22. (Contributed by NM, 13-Oct-2004.)
blocks.origin:
thm ruc() {
  |- wbr(cn, csdm, cr)
} = {
  mpbir2an(wbr(cn, csdm, cr), wbr(cn, cdom, cr), wn(wbr(cn, cen, cr)))
  mp2(wbr(cn, cdom, cr), wcel(cr, universe), wss(cn, cr))
  reex()
  nnssre()
  ssdomg(cr, universe, cn)
  mtbir(wbr(cn, cen, cr), wex(hs0, wf1o(cv(hs0), cn, cr)))
  nex(hs0, wf1o(cv(hs0), cn, cr))
  mto(wf1o(cv(hs0), cn, cr), wfo(cv(hs0), cn, cr))
  ruclem13(cv(hs0))
  f1ofo(cv(hs0), cn, cr)
  bren(hs0, cn, cr)
  brsdom(cn, cr)
  diff.hs0.c(cn)
  diff.hs0.c(cr)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm ruc() {
  ⊢ ℕ[≺]ℝ
} = {
  mpbir2an(ℕ[≺]ℝ, ℕ[≼]ℝ, ¬ ℕ[≅]ℝ)
  mp2(ℕ[≼]ℝ, ℝ ∈ 𝕌, ℕ ⊆ ℝ)
  reex()
  nnssre()
  ssdomg(cr, universe, cn)
  mtbir(ℕ[≅]ℝ, ∃(hs0,(hs0 : ℕ ↔ ℝ)))
  nex(hs0, (hs0 : ℕ ↔ ℝ))
  mto((hs0 : ℕ ↔ ℝ), (hs0 : ℕ ↠ ℝ))
  ruclem13(hs0)
  f1ofo(hs0, cn, cr)
  bren(hs0, cn, cr)
  brsdom(cn, cr)
  diff.hs0.c(cn)
  diff.hs0.c(cr)
}

blocks.name: resdomq
blocks.content: The set of rationals is strictly less equinumerous than the set of reals ( ` RR ` strictly dominates ` QQ ` ). (Contributed by NM, 18-Dec-2004.)

blocks.name: aleph1re
